title: Shirahoshi as Poseidon Will Play a Major Role in the Final War
theoryText: Shirahoshi's revelation about keeping Otohime's secret demonstrates her incredible emotional strength and willpower. This, combined with her identity as the Ancient Weapon Poseidon who can command Sea Kings, suggests she will play a crucial role in the series' endgame. Her commitment to her mother's ideals of peace, even in the face of knowing her killer, parallels themes that will likely emerge in the final conflict between different ideologies in the One Piece world.
author: One Piece Fan Community

spoilerWarning.spoilerDescription: References Shirahoshi's identity as an Ancient Weapon and implications for the series endgame

evidence: Shirahoshi is confirmed to be Poseidon, one of the three Ancient Weapons
Her ability to command Sea Kings could destroy the world if she wished
Her commitment to peace despite knowing her mother's killer shows exceptional character
The parallel between her and Luffy as significant figures in changing the world
counterArguments: Shirahoshi's role may be more symbolic than active in the final war
Her powers may be used defensively rather than offensively

title: Luffy Will Destroy Fish-Man Island to Save It
theoryText: The prophecy that Luffy will destroy Fish-Man Island, combined with his appearance as both potential destroyer and savior in episode 553, suggests that Luffy will eventually destroy the physical island but in doing so, save its people. This could involve destroying the Red Line, which would cause debris to crush Fish-Man Island but also fulfill the ancient dream of fish-men and humans living together in the sunlight. Shirahoshi's role as Poseidon would be crucial in evacuating everyone using Sea Kings.
author: One Piece Theory Community

counterArguments: Prophecies in One Piece don't always come true literally
The destruction could be metaphorical rather than physical
Other interpretations of how the island could be 'destroyed'

title: Hody Jones Represents the Cycle of Inherited Hatred
theoryText: Hody's role as the killer of Queen Otohime and his framing of a human pirate represents how hatred can be manufactured and perpetuated across generations. The theory suggests that Hody has no real reason to hate humans - he's simply a product of his environment, raised to hate. This contrasts with Shirahoshi's choice to break the cycle of hatred by honoring her mother's wish. This theme will likely be explored further, revealing that Hody's hatred is empty and learned rather than based on any real grievance.
author: Fish-Man Island Arc Analysts

The arc's themes center on breaking cycles of hatred
